Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation2: A procedural hearing on a minor matter can easily be postponed if necessary.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, the clock blinking 7:58 p.m. Every Sunday at 8, I called my parents. It was our ritual, a thread tying me to home no matter how far my work took me. Tonight, though, I was still at the office, files spread across my desk, prepping for a procedural hearing scheduled for tomorrow morning. It wasn’t urgent—postponing it would be simple, just a quick email to the court. But my client, anxious and new to the legal system, had called twice today, desperate for reassurance that things were moving forward.

My phone buzzed. Mom’s name lit up the screen. I could already hear her gentle voice, asking about my week, wanting to know if I was eating well, if I was happy. I felt the weight of her expectations, the comfort she found in our calls. At the same time, I pictured my client, waiting for answers, counting on me to be present and prepared. My heart tugged in two directions, each role demanding my attention, each expectation valid. I stared at the phone, torn, the seconds ticking by as I wrestled with what to do next.
